title-group.article-title: Bell Palsy in a Neonate With Rapid Response to Oral Corticosteroids
title-group.subtitle: A Case Report

abstract.p: Idiopathic facial nerve palsy, also known as Bell palsy is rare in the neonatal age group. Other more common causes such as birth trauma; infections, especially otitis media; and congenital malformations need to be excluded. We present here a 4-week-old neonate with Bell palsy who responded rapidly to oral corticosteroids. Such an early presentation of idiopathic facial nerve palsy and use of corticosteroids in neonates is scarcely reported in the literature.

body.p: Bell palsy is an acute, generally unilateral peripheral facial nerve dysfunction causing paralysis or weakness of facial musculature that is not associated with other cranial neuropathies or brainstem dysfunction. Viral infections, vascular ischemia, autoimmune inflammatory phenomenon, and heredity have been proposed as underlying mechanisms.1 It accounts for the majority of cases of facial weakness in children followed by infections and trauma. It is rarely encountered in neonates, in whom traumatic delivery, congenital malformations, and infections including otitis media need to be excluded. This makes early recognition and treatment important. We present here a 4-week-old neonate with Bell palsy who responded rapidly to oral corticosteroids and physiotherapy.

sec.title: Case Report
sec.p: A 5-week-old female infant presented to us with complaints of acute-onset deviation of angle of mouth to left side while crying, drooling of milk from right side, and inability to close the right eye for the previous 1 week. There was mild upper respiratory tract infection 5 days before this event. There was no history of fever or rash. The baby was born by full-term normal vaginal delivery at hospital with no dystocia, forceps use, or suction application. There were no adverse antenatal or perinatal events. She had received BCG vaccination at birth and was on exclusive breast-feeding. The baby weighed 3.5 kg and her head circumference was 36.5 cm. She was alert and active. There was facial asymmetry with complete lower motor neuron type right facial nerve paralysis (Figure 1). No other focal deficits, cranial nerve involvement, or malformations were noted. Extraocular movements were intact and pupils were normally reacting to light. Ear examination was normal. She demonstrated age-appropriate response to sound, and hearing evaluation done clinically and by evoked acoustic emissions (OAE) was also normal. The rest of the systemic examination was unremarkable.

caption.p: A 5-week-old female infant showing facial asymmetry with complete lower motor neuron type right facial nerve paralysis.

sec.p: Laboratory investigations showed hemoglobin 120 g/L, total leucocyte count 12.8 × 109/L (neutrophils 74%, lymphocytes 23%, monocytes 2%, eosinophils 1%), platelet count 41 × 109/µL and C-reactive protein 0.5 mg/dL. Contrast-enhanced magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain (with temporal sections) was normal along with normal facial nerve canal. She received 2 weeks of oral corticosteroids followed by tapering over the next 4 weeks. Follow-up examination after 6 weeks of corticosteroids showed remarkable improvement and the child had mild deviation of the angle of the mouth to the left side at the initiation of cry only, but she could now close her right eye (Figure 2).

caption.p: Follow-up examination after 6 weeks of corticosteroids showing remarkable improvement.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Facial palsy in the newborn is rare, occurring in 0.23% to 1.8% of live births, and 78% to 90% of the cases are associated with birth trauma.2 Treatable infections like otitis media have been reported by as early as 2 weeks of life.3 Neonatal idiopathic facial nerve palsy as seen in our case has been scarcely reported in the literature.4,5

Literature suggests no uniform indication for computed tomography in Bell palsy. Swart et al have recommended high-resolution computed tomography for patients with a history of chronic otitis media, otoscopically demonstrable mass, previous mastoid surgery, or temporal bone fractures.6 Otherwise, pre-and postcontrast–enhanced MRI of the brain, including brainstem, parotids, and temporal bone is indicated. Contrast enhancement of the first genu and proximal tympanic segment is considered normal,6 whereas that of geniculate ganglion within the labyrinthine segment of the facial nerve is a common radiologic finding in Bell palsy.7 In the index patient, MRI of the head with temporal sections was obtained to rule out other etiologies like congenital malformations, birth trauma, temporal bone fractures, cerebral contusions, acute or chronic otitis, cholesteatoma, tumors, compression trauma, and herpes zoster in a newborn.8 In addition, several central facial palsies may affect eyelid closure and give the impression of peripheral paralysis.

Pharmacological treatment options in pediatric Bell palsy are controversial. Since inflammation and edema have been implicated in its pathogenesis, corticosteroids have been used to minimize nerve damage and hasten recovery9; however, other studies have shown no benefit of corticosteroids.10 The American Academy of Neurology Guidelines promote early initiation of corticosteroids and antiviral medications, though evidence in both adults and children is inconclusive.11 A recent Cochrane systematic review has shown significant benefits from corticosteroids in Bell palsy; of the 8 studies included, only 1 had pediatric patients but not infants.12 No standard treatment is postulated for neonates because of the rarity of the disorder in this age group and lack of definitive, statistically valid studies considering the benefit of corticosteroids in them. Hence, in view of the evidence of benefit in older children as well as our own experience with older children, we decided to go ahead with a short course of corticosteroid therapy in the given patient. As there was no clinical and radiologic evidence of herpes infection, acyclovir was not used. We have documented a rapid response to oral corticosteroids with significant recovery at 6 weeks of therapy.

As is known, the objective methods of evaluating hearing in an infant are the auditory brainstem response and the evoked otoacoustic emissions. The former is an electrophysiological measurement of activity in auditory nerve and brainstem pathways whereas the latter measures cochlear response to a sound stimulus. Both are not true tests of hearing as they do not assess cortical processing of the sound. Behavioral pure tone audiometry remains the standard for hearing evaluation in the older child.13 Subjectively, the attainment of following speech-language-auditory milestones in infants from birth to 3 months of age is reassuring: startles to loud noise, awakens to sound, blinks or widens eyes in response to noise.13 However, this is a gross evaluation and can miss unilateral hearing loss.

The prognosis of pediatric facial nerve palsy depends on the underlying etiology; recovery rates for Bell palsy have been shown to be 80% to 100%, 73% for infections and 67% for trauma.14 Age less than 10 years and acute onset have been associated with better prognosis.15 The most frequent cause of unilateral congenital facial palsy is birth trauma related to difficult delivery. Risk factors are forceps application, birth weight more than 3500 g, and primiparity.2 The injury from forceps is induced by pressure of the posterior blade over the bone overlying the vertical segment of the nerve or soft tissue compression over the exit through styloid foramen.16 Complete transaction of the facial nerve due to birth trauma is rare; more commonly, it is a transient facial neurapraxia.17 Because of its rarity, the prognosis of Bell palsy in neonates is not clearly known.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Facial nerve palsy can be seen as early as the neonatal period without any birth trauma, infections or congenital malformations and responds well to oral corticosteroids and physiotherapy.
